M: (law) the act of substituting of one creditor for another
offer to buy, as of stocks and shares
I subscribe to your view on abortion
We take the Times every day
(of a contract or will or other document) having a signature written at the end
someone who contracts to receive and pay for a service or a certain number of issues of a publication
someone who contributes (or promises to contribute) a sum of money
written or printed below and to one side of another character
a payment for consecutive issues of a newspaper or magazine for a given period of time
agreement expressed by (or as if expressed by) signing your name
the act of signing your name; writing your signature (as on a document)
the deed was attested by the subscription of his signature
a section of a section; a part of a part; i.e., a part of something already divided
happening at a time subsequent to a reference time
he's going to the store but he'll be back here later
the condition of being something that is useful in reaching an end or carrying out a plan
all his actions were in subservience to the general plan
editors and journalists who express opinions in print that are opposed to the interests of the rich are dismissed and replaced by subservient ones"-G. B. Shaw
a set whose members are members of another set; a set contained within another set
low-growing woody shrub or perennial with woody base
sink to a lower level or form a depression
the mud subsides when the waters become calm
money (or other benefits) obtained as a subsidy
The arts in Europe are heavily subsidized
secure the assistance of by granting a subsidy, as of nations or military forces
having partial financial support from public funds
someone who assists or supports by giving a subsidy
a grant paid by a government to an enterprise that benefits the public
a subsidy for research in artificial intelligence
social security provided only a bare subsistence
farming is a hard means of subsistence
the state of existing in reality; having substance
the layer of soil between the topsoil and bedrock
(of speed) less than that of sound in a designated medium
a space that is contained within another space
(biology) a taxonomic group that is a division of a species; usually arises as a consequence of geographical isolation within a species
the real physical matter of which a person or thing consists
DNA is the substance of our genes
material of a particular kind or constitution
the immune response recognizes invading substances
a particular kind or species of matter with uniform properties
shigella is one of the most toxic substances known to man
having a firm basis in reality and being therefore important, meaningful, or considerable
having substance or capable of being treated as fact; not imaginary
a mere dream, neither substantial nor practical
most ponderous and substantial things"- Shakespeare
the quality of being substantial or having substance
The president's trip will substantiate good relations with the former enemy country
of or relating to or having the nature or function of a substantive (i.e. a noun or noun equivalent)
any word or group of words functioning as a noun
defining rights and duties as opposed to giving the rules by which rights and duties are established
a subsidiary station where electricity is transformed for distribution by a low-voltage network
(of words) interchangeable in a given context without changing the import of the expression
put in the place of another; switch seemingly equivalent items
the con artist replaced the original with a fake Rembrandt
substitute regular milk with fat-free milk
synonyms can be interchanged without a changing the context's meaning
The young teacher had to substitute for the sick colleague
The skim milk substitutes for cream--we are on a strict diet
She stood in for the soprano who suffered from a cold
an event in which one thing is substituted for another
the replacement of lost blood by a transfusion of donor blood
the act of putting one thing or person in the place of another: "he sent Smith in for Jones but the substitution came too late to help"
the substance that is acted upon by an enzyme or ferment
a surface on which an organism grows or is attached
the gardener talked about the proper substrate for acid-loving plants
any stratum or layer lying underneath another
an indigenous language that contributes features to the language of an invading people who impose their language on the indigenous population
the Celtic languages of Britain are a substrate for English
a string that is part of a longer string
